entry.title: Combined summary - # error "Bitcoin cannot be compiled without assertions." <<<<NOT
entry.summary: The use of assertions is necessary for maintaining proper sanity of the client and network, but it is important to ensure that they have no side effects and that they do not slow down the system. Bitcoin Core currently requires assertions to be enabled in order to build and prevent costly incorrect behavior. However, assertions must meet certain performance requirements and cannot do expensive, redundant checks in performance-critical code.There have been concerns about the current use of assertions, with some suggesting that debugging assertions should be introduced exclusively for expensive, redundant checks and disabled by NDEBUG. In response, Jannis Froese suggested changing the current use of asserts to a definition that is independent of NDEBUG. He also recommended introducing a second class of debugging asserts that would be exclusively for expensive, redundant checks and would be disabled by NDEBUG.Jeff Garzik, a Bitcoin core developer and open source evangelist, suggests the use of the glog library's CHECK macros, which print stack traces when they fail and can help make software more robust. Moreover, it is important to make it easy for users to send reports that are useful to programmers. Expensive diagnostics are fine, but they should be compiled in and disabled by default at runtime so that they do not slow down the system when turned off.The issue with the Bitcoin code regarding assertions that aren't in previous releases has been addressed through a commit and code with all side effects removed from the assertions. The code with unit tests working has also been made available, along with a video series on building Bitcoind.exe and the static libraries in NDEBUG (release) mode. Additionally, there is a video on building an alternate coin-qt.exe in release mode (gcc version) and running it.It was mentioned that assertion errors that happen to people running Bitcoin Core are not caused by software bugs but database corruption errors. Therefore, instead of raising an assertion error, proposing a -reindex would be more suitable for those problems which are probably recoverable in a certain specific way.Despite the importance of assertions, it is important to note that assertions should have no side effects and that the codebase has been cleaned up to remove any assertions with side effects. Professional codebases often require assertions to be enabled, and Bitcoin Core currently fails to build if assertions are disabled. The wisdom of this decision was demonstrated when an additional side-effect having assert was contributed soon after.The use of their own assertion macros may be superior, but making larger changes all at once would be unwise since the codebase is a production environment. The wisdom of refusing to compile in an untested, unsupported configuration has been demonstrated.It is suggested that everyone who thinks they know what they are doing when they write C++ should read the book "Gotcha #28 Side Effects". It is also questioned why these sub-standard coding practices were not fixed earlier and continued to be expanded in later releases.In conclusion, the use of assertions is necessary for maintaining proper sanity of the client and network, but it is important to ensure that they have no side effects and that they do not slow down the system. The glog library's CHECK macros can help make software more robust, and it is important to make it easy for users to send reports that are useful to programmers.
